Title1: If your intention is pure, the universe becomes your co-author
Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: ’s story is one of transformation. A traveller who has visited over a hundred countries, he once worked as an international cabin crew member. Today, he inspires others as a
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: , animal advocate, and author of ‘
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title1: Xi–Trump meeting and the global order
Title2: President Paudel to return home this afternoon
Paragraph1_of_URL1: The recent meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump has reignited debate over the future of global power transitions. Beyond the symbolic handshake, the encounter represents an attempt to redefine the grammar of great-power engagement at a time of fragmentation, economic uncertainty and deep mistrust. Whether read as reconciliation or recalibration, the dialogue reflects how Washington and Beijing are wrestling to shape the next global order—one that will inevitably affect the Indo-Pacific region and smaller states like Nepal.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: President Ramchandra Paudel is returning home this afternoon after participating in the Second World Summit for Social Development held in Doha, the capital of Qatar. During the visit, President Paudel addressed the main session of the Summit last Tuesday.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: While much commentary has focused on optics and personal chemistry, the meeting’s underlying message was clear: Confrontation without communication risks global instability. Xi’s call for “mutual respect” and Trump’s rhetorical shift toward “constructive competition” signal a tactical pause rather than a transformation. Discussions reportedly covered trade, technology, Taiwan and the South China Sea, highlighting how security and economics are now inseparable in the US–China relations.

Title1: Xi–Trump meeting and the global order

Paragraph1_of_URL1: The recent meeting between Chinese President Xi Jinping and US President Donald Trump has reignited debate over the future of global power transitions. Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: While much commentary has focused on optics and personal chemistry, the meeting’s underlying message was clear: Confrontation without communication risks global instability. Xi’s call for “mutual respect” and Trump’s rhetorical shift toward “constructive competition” signal a tactical pause rather than a transformation. Discussions reportedly covered trade, technology, Taiwan and the South China Sea, highlighting how security and economics are now inseparable in the US–China relations.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: In a public notice issued on Thursday, the Scouts said the company had not cleared the dues even after the property was sealed. Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title1: The Dolma dodge
Title2: President Paudel to return home this afternoon
Paragraph1_of_URL1: The Sushila Karki government was formed in the wake of the Gen Z uprising with the singular mandate of holding elections on March 5, 2026. As such, besides other day to day activities, its whole focus should be trained on that task—for that is the only metric with which its success will be measured. By the same token, the interim government should also refrain from making any decisions with long-term consequences for the country. Only a sovereign parliament and an elected government have the authority to weigh in on such matters. Yet, strangely, for a government formed on an explicit anti-corruption platform, it has made such a wholly avoidable blunder by granting tax exemption to Dolma Impact Fund, which has been challenging investment into Nepal through a shell company registered in the tax haven of Mauritius. Dolma, which has investments in 16 companies, had long sought such an exemption. But successive governments had carefully avoided stepping on this minefield.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: The government based its decision on the Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement (DTAA) signed with Mauritius. The exemption will allow Dolma to save taxes on its income in Nepal, financially benefiting the fund and making it easier to repatriate dividends abroad. After a previous attempt to exempt Ncell, a telecom provider, ended in a dispute, the Nepali tax authorities had cautioned the Karki government not to make the same blunder in Dolma’s case. The Ncell dispute, also rooted in claims of double taxation, had reached the Hague-based international tribunal before Nepal’s Supreme Court and the tribunal both ruled that Ncell’s income was taxable in Nepal. Despite that precedent, the finance ministry has now chosen to grant Dolma a tax waiver.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

After a previous attempt to exempt Ncell, a telecom provider, ended in a dispute, the Nepali tax authorities had cautioned the Karki government not to make the same blunder in Dolma’s case. The Ncell dispute, also rooted in claims of double taxation, had reached the Hague-based international tribunal before Nepal’s Supreme Court and the tribunal both ruled that Ncell’s income was taxable in Nepal. Despite that precedent, the finance ministry has now chosen to grant Dolma a tax waiver.

Title1: The Dolma dodge
Title2: Executive Director Poudel appointed NRB spokesperson
Paragraph1_of_URL1: The Sushila Karki government was formed in the wake of the Gen Z uprising with the singular mandate of holding elections on March 5, 2026. As such, besides other day to day activities, its whole focus should be trained on that task—for that is the only metric with which its success will be measured. By the same token, the interim government should also refrain from making any decisions with long-term consequences for the country. Only a sovereign parliament and an elected government have the authority to weigh in on such matters. Yet, strangely, for a government formed on an explicit anti-corruption platform, it has made such a wholly avoidable blunder by granting tax exemption to Dolma Impact Fund, which has been challenging investment into Nepal through a shell company registered in the tax haven of Mauritius. Dolma, which has investments in 16 companies, had long sought such an exemption. But successive governments had carefully avoided stepping on this minefield.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: The government based its decision on the Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement (DTAA) signed with Mauritius. There has long been ambiguity over whether such foreign investments are taxable under Nepal’s Income Tax Act, 2002. The exemption will allow Dolma to save taxes on its income in Nepal, financially benefiting the fund and making it easier to repatriate dividends abroad. After a previous attempt to exempt Ncell, a telecom provider, ended in a dispute, the Nepali tax authorities had cautioned the Karki government not to make the same blunder in Dolma’s case. The Ncell dispute, also rooted in claims of double taxation, had reached the Hague-based international tribunal before Nepal’s Supreme Court and the tribunal both ruled that Ncell’s income was taxable in Nepal. Despite that precedent, the finance ministry has now chosen to grant Dolma a tax waiver.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 6: Executive Director Guru Prasad Poudel has been appointed as the spokesperson of Nepal Rastra Bank.

Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change

Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

At the special ceremony held today at local Bhrikuti Mandap, unity was announced among the leftist parties including the Maoist Centre, Unified Socialist, Nepal Socialist Party, Janasamajbadi Party Nepal, Nepal Communist Party, CPN (Maoist Socialist) and CPN (Communist).
Paragraph2_of_URL2: After the declaration of unification, the unified party has been christened as 'Nepali Communist Party'. Party top leaders and workers, including Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda', coordinator of the Maoist Centre, Madhav Kumar Nepal, chairman of the Unified Socialist, senior Maoist leader Narayan Kaji Shrestha, senior leader of the Unified Socialist Bamdev Gautam, Mahendra Ray Yadav, chairman of the Nepal Socialist Party, and Chiran Pun, general secretary of the Nepal Communist Party, among other leaders and party activists, attended the unity declaration gathering.

The unification national conference organised here on Wednesday elected Madhav Kumar Nepal as its joint-coordinator. Member of THE presidium, Mahindra Raya Yadav, proposed Dahal to the post of coordinator and Nepal as joint-coordinator of the newly formed party.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: The conference had endorsed the proposal unanimously. On the occasion, senior leader of the Nepali Communist Party, Bamdev Gautam, leaders- Narayan Kaji Shrestha and Pampha Bhusal expressed the belief that the new party would fulfill the mandate of social revolution. Meanwhile, General Secretary of the erstwhile CPN (US) Party Ghanashyam Bhusal and leader Ram Kumari Jhankri and some other leaders have not joined the new party, while expressing their protests against the unification.§

Title1: Chitlang defeat Deurali in President League
Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: The ANFA President League kicked off at Hetauda’s Gauritar Stadium with Chitlang FC defeating Deurali Youth Club 4-1 in the opening match on Wednesday.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Chandan Kumar Das became the first scorer of the tournament as he gave Chitlang the lead in the 32nd minute. And before the first half, with four minutes of additional time, came to an end, Chitlang scored two more, that too within a minute.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title1: 10th National Games slated for February 13-19 next year
Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: The 10th edition of the National Games got a new date during the 123rd board meeting of the National Sports Council on Wednesday.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: In the board meeting chaired by Minister for Youth and Sports Bablu Gupta, the National Sports Council (NSC), seven provinces and three departmental clubs agreed on organising the country’s biggest multi-sport event in Karnali Province from February 13 to 19. The meeting was broadcast live according to the minister’s pledge.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Nepal were playing four matches in the tri-series in Dubai—two against the UAE and two against the USA. However, Stuart Law’s boys could not gain a single point this time, having lost all four.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: Nepali footballers staged a protest outside the All Nepal Football Association (ANFA) Complex in Satdobato on Thursday, demanding the immediate resumption of the Martyr’s Memorial ‘A’ Division League.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Players had gathered at 11am but were stopped at the main gate. Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: In the remote village of Bayal in Bajura, a woman was forced to give birth on the roadside just a year ago. Around one o'clock in the middle of the night, there was a commotion at the home of health worker Vinita Bisht Katuwal. Someone had arrived, urgently asking her to open the door. They explained that a pregnant woman on her way to the health post had gone into labor on the road. Hearing this news, Vinita immediately grabbed her delivery kit and ran into the darkness to reach the woman.

The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Authority (NDRRMA) informed that in 24 hours- from November 3 to 4, nine such incidents were recorded across the country. Jhapa, Morang, Mahottari, Sarlahi, Rautahat, Bara, Gorkha, Parbat and Kailali districts witnessed the fire incidents, the NDRRMA said, adding that total 18 incidents occurred in the country in two days alone, claiming the lives of three persons and injuring eight others.

Party top leaders and workers, including Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda', coordinator of the Maoist Centre, Madhav Kumar Nepal, chairman of the Unified Socialist, senior Maoist leader Narayan Kaji Shrestha, senior leader of the Unified Socialist Bamdev Gautam, Mahendra Ray Yadav, chairman of the Nepal Socialist Party, and Chiran Pun, general secretary of the Nepal Communist Party, among other leaders and party activists, attended the unity declaration gathering.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: The extent of the revocations, first reported by Washington Examiner, reflects a broad immigration crackdown initiated when Trump came into office, deporting an unprecedented number of migrants including some who held valid visas.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Gathered in front of parliament, the Vucic supporters, many of whom travelled to the capital in buses organised by Vucic’s party, waved national flags and chanted “Vucic, the Serb” and “Serbia” as loudspeakers played patriotic songs.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: The blistering rise of Zohran Mamdani to become mayor of New York City has offered encouragement to left-wing parties across Europe that an unabashedly radical agenda could help turn the tide against right-wing forces at home.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Parties from London to Berlin cheered Mamdani, a 34-year-old self-described democratic socialist whose viral videos and promise of rent controls and taxing the rich in a city seen as a beacon of global capitalism struck a chord with voters.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title1: Bihar Assembly Election, phase 1: These key contestants and constituencies are the ones to watch
Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: Bihar is ready for the first major political test of 2025. On November 6, voters across 121 Assembly seats in 18 districts will step out to choose who leads the state next. This is the opening round of the two-phase election. The remaining constituencies will go to polls on November 11 closing a dramatic campaign season filled with loud rallies, sharp speeches, and high promises.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Both sides know what is at stake. The National Democratic Alliance, led by the BJP and its allies JD(U), LJP, HAM, and RLM, wants to protect its hold on power, much like it did in 2020 when it edged past the Opposition with 125 seats.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change

Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: “If this happens to the president, where does that leave all the young women in our country,” said Sheinbaum, Mexico’s first female president. “No man has the right to abuse women’s personal space.”
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: How many of you have drunk turmeric milk after getting hurt? This drink is not only given when you are injured, but also when you are suffering from a cold. According to our elders, a mixture of turmeric and milk is a cure for every illness. An interesting point is that recently, this same milk is becoming popular abroad under the name 'Golden Milk'. Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: In Vietnam’s Gia Lai province, some 350,000 people were expected to have been evacuated by the middle of the day as authorities warned of heavy rains and damaging winds that could cause flooding in low-lying areas and disrupt agricultural activity.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title1: Afghanistan and Pakistan return to Istanbul for more peace talks
Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: Afghanistan and Pakistan will resume peace talks in Istanbul on Thursday, both nations said, after a previous round ended without agreeing a lasting truce.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Militaries from the South Asian neighbours clashed last month, with dozens killed in the worst such violence since the Taliban returned to power in Kabul in 2021.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: The Czech centre-right government agreed to resign, Prime Minister Petr Fiala said on Thursday, a formal step to handing over power to a new cabinet being formed by populist billionaire Andrej Babis after his October election victory.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: The outgoing cabinet remains in office until Babis' team are formally appointed, which is not expected for several more weeks.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title1: Angelina Jolie visits Ukraine’s frontline city Kherson
Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: Hollywood actor Angelina Jolie has visited one of Ukraine’s most dangerous frontline cities and a neighbouring region, meeting medical staff, volunteers and civilians living under constant attacks from Russian troops.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: "At a time when governments around the world are turning their backs on the protection of civilians, their strength, and their support for each other is humbling," Jolie said in a statement released on Thursday by the Legacy of War Foundation, which supported her visit to Kherson and nearby Mykolaiv.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title1: Angelina Jolie visits Ukraine’s frontline city Kherson
Title2: Ten left forces, including CPN (Maoist Centre) and CPN (Unified Socialist), join hands
Paragraph1_of_URL1: Hollywood actor Angelina Jolie has visited one of Ukraine’s most dangerous frontline cities and a neighbouring region, meeting medical staff, volunteers and civilians living under constant attacks from Russian troops.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: Unification has been announced today among various leftist parties, including the CPN (Maoist Centre) and the CPN (Unified Socialist). At the special ceremony held today at local Bhrikuti Mandap, unity was announced among the leftist parties including the Maoist Centre, Unified Socialist, Nepal Socialist Party, Janasamajbadi Party Nepal, Nepal Communist Party, CPN (Maoist Socialist) and CPN (Communist).
Paragraph2_of_URL1: "At a time when governments around the world are turning their backs on the protection of civilians, their strength, and their support for each other is humbling," Jolie said in a statement released on Thursday by the Legacy of War Foundation, which supported her visit to Kherson and nearby Mykolaiv.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: After the declaration of unification, the unified party has been christened as 'Nepali Communist Party'. Party top leaders and workers, including Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda', coordinator of the Maoist Centre, Madhav Kumar Nepal, chairman of the Unified Socialist, senior Maoist leader Narayan Kaji Shrestha, senior leader of the Unified Socialist Bamdev Gautam, Mahendra Ray Yadav, chairman of the Nepal Socialist Party, and Chiran Pun, general secretary of the Nepal Communist Party, among other leaders and party activists, attended the unity declaration gathering.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Both the RSF and the Sudanese army have agreed to various ceasefire proposals during their two-and-a-half-year-old war, though none have succeeded. US President Donald Trump's administration has said it was working towards ending fighting in Sudan.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: On October 16, a month after its formation, the interim government asked Nepal’s ambassadors to China, Germany, Israel, Malaysia, Qatar, Russia, Saudi Arabia, Spain, the United Kingdom, the United States, and Japan to return home by November 6.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: The previous bridge was swept away by floods eight years ago, leaving more than 150,000 residents struggling with mobility. Although a proposal for budget approval was submitted two years ago, the Ministry of Finance and the National Planning Commission have yet to approve, halting the project.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: The Butwal bench of the Tulsipur High Court on Thursday orders authorities to submit the initial case files related to the cooperative fraud and organised crime case against Rastriya Swatantra Party (RSP) chair Rabi Lamichhane and former Gorkha Media Network director Chhabi Lal Joshi.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: The division bench of judges Basudev Acharya and Om Prasad Aryal issued the order after hearings from both sides. Earlier, the hearing scheduled for October 30 was postponed following a petition from Joshi’s legal team.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title1: Ncell partners with Metlife to offer data packs with insurance coverage
Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: Ncell has partnered with MetLife Nepal to launch a new service, ‘Data Sangai Jeevan Beema’, which allows customers to purchase mobile data packs bundled with life and critical illness insurance coverage.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Under the scheme, users can choose between two packages, Ncell said in a press release on Thursday.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Title1: Gandaki government cuts administrative spending to fund Rs 2 billion reconstruction
Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: The Gandaki Province government has announced sweeping cuts in administrative expenses to free up around Rs2 billion for reconstruction of public infrastructure damaged during the Gen Z protests in September.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: The Cabinet meeting held on October 28 decided to partially or completely suspend spending under several recurrent budget headings, including vehicle purchases, official travel, hospitality and furniture procurement. According to Minister for Economic Affairs Takaraj Gurung, the government will cut 80 percent of the computer software purchase budget, 50 percent each from monitoring and evaluation, travel and publications, 25 percent each from hospitality and miscellaneous headings, and 20 percent each from fuel and vehicle maintenance.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

At the special ceremony held today at local Bhrikuti Mandap, unity was announced among the leftist parties including the Maoist Centre, Unified Socialist, Nepal Socialist Party, Janasamajbadi Party Nepal, Nepal Communist Party, CPN (Maoist Socialist) and CPN (Communist).

Paragraph2_of_URL2: After the declaration of unification, the unified party has been christened as 'Nepali Communist Party'. Party top leaders and workers, including Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda', coordinator of the Maoist Centre, Madhav Kumar Nepal, chairman of the Unified Socialist, senior Maoist leader Narayan Kaji Shrestha, senior leader of the Unified Socialist Bamdev Gautam, Mahendra Ray Yadav, chairman of the Nepal Socialist Party, and Chiran Pun, general secretary of the Nepal Communist Party, among other leaders and party activists, attended the unity declaration gathering.

Meanwhile, General Secretary of the erstwhile CPN (US) Party Ghanashyam Bhusal and leader Ram Kumari Jhankri and some other leaders have not joined the new party, while expressing their protests against the unification.§

Title1: President Paudel returns home after attending Doha social development summit
Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: President Ramchandra Paudel returned to Nepal on Thursday after completing his official visit to Doha, Qatar, where he led the Nepali delegation to the Second World Summit for Social Development.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Paudel
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Paragraph1_of_URL1: President Ramchandra Paudel returned to Nepal on Thursday after completing his official visit to Doha, Qatar, where he led the Nepali delegation to the Second World Summit for Social Development.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: The police have arrested a person involved in vandalism and arson on the Police Circle at New Baneshwor during the Gen Z protest. The District Police Office, Kathmandu arrested Shivam Chaudhary, 18, originally from Dhanusha district and currently staying at Mahalaxmi municipality of Lalitpur.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Paudel
Paragraph2_of_URL2: He had involved in torching and vandalizing Police Circe and the Parliament Building at New Baneshwor on September 9.

Title1: President Paudel returns home after attending Doha social development summit
Title2: Nanak Jayanti being observed today
Paragraph1_of_URL1: President Ramchandra Paudel returned to Nepal on Thursday after completing his official visit to Doha, Qatar, where he led the Nepali delegation to the Second World Summit for Social Development.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: Guru Nanak Jayanti is being observed by the Sikh community living in Nepal and different parts of the world today. Guru Nanak is the founder of Sikh religion. The spiritual leader had inspired the humanity for tolerance, compassion and love.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Paudel
Paragraph2_of_URL2: The Sikh community celebrates the day with much reverence. The prayers are held, sermons recited and activities of human service performed on this occasion. Equality, peace and nonviolence are special messages of Guru Nanak.

Title1: President Paudel returns home after attending Doha social development summit
Title2: Natural disasters, fire incidents on rise
Paragraph1_of_URL1: President Ramchandra Paudel returned to Nepal on Thursday after completing his official visit to Doha, Qatar, where he led the Nepali delegation to the Second World Summit for Social Development.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: The fire incidents are on rise of late. The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Authority (NDRRMA) informed that in 24 hours- from November 3 to 4, nine such incidents were recorded across the country. Jhapa, Morang, Mahottari, Sarlahi, Rautahat, Bara, Gorkha, Parbat and Kailali districts witnessed the fire incidents, the NDRRMA said, adding that total 18 incidents occurred in the country in two days alone, claiming the lives of three persons and injuring eight others.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Paudel
Paragraph2_of_URL2: The incidents caused the damages worth Rs 1.1 million. Storm occurred in Rasuwa caused massive damage. The avalanche damaged a local hotel at Langtang of Gosaikunda-4. Even the landslides occurred in Bhojpur, Khotang and Lalitpur districts.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: The Nepal Bar Association (NBA) has said that it is seriously concerned about the decision to recall the ambassadors, citing that the matter is under consideration in the Supreme Court.

Title1: President Paudel returns home after attending Doha social development summit
Title2: Ten left forces, including CPN (Maoist Centre) and CPN (Unified Socialist), join hands
Paragraph1_of_URL1: President Ramchandra Paudel returned to Nepal on Thursday after completing his official visit to Doha, Qatar, where he led the Nepali delegation to the Second World Summit for Social Development.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: Unification has been announced today among various leftist parties, including the CPN (Maoist Centre) and the CPN (Unified Socialist). At the special ceremony held today at local Bhrikuti Mandap, unity was announced among the leftist parties including the Maoist Centre, Unified Socialist, Nepal Socialist Party, Janasamajbadi Party Nepal, Nepal Communist Party, CPN (Maoist Socialist) and CPN (Communist).
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Paudel
Paragraph2_of_URL2: After the declaration of unification, the unified party has been christened as 'Nepali Communist Party'. Party top leaders and workers, including Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda', coordinator of the Maoist Centre, Madhav Kumar Nepal, chairman of the Unified Socialist, senior Maoist leader Narayan Kaji Shrestha, senior leader of the Unified Socialist Bamdev Gautam, Mahendra Ray Yadav, chairman of the Nepal Socialist Party, and Chiran Pun, general secretary of the Nepal Communist Party, among other leaders and party activists, attended the unity declaration gathering.

Title1: President Paudel returns home after attending Doha social development summit
Title2: Dahal elected coordinator of Nepali Communist Party, Nepal as joint-coordinator
Paragraph1_of_URL1: President Ramchandra Paudel returned to Nepal on Thursday after completing his official visit to Doha, Qatar, where he led the Nepali delegation to the Second World Summit for Social Development.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda' has been elected as coordinator of Nepali Communist Party, formed after the unification of 10 political parties including CPN (Maoist Centre) and CPN (Unified Socialist). The unification national conference organised here on Wednesday elected Madhav Kumar Nepal as its joint-coordinator. Member of THE presidium, Mahindra Raya Yadav, proposed Dahal to the post of coordinator and Nepal as joint-coordinator of the newly formed party.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Paudel
Paragraph2_of_URL2: The conference had endorsed the proposal unanimously. On the occasion, senior leader of the Nepali Communist Party, Bamdev Gautam, leaders- Narayan Kaji Shrestha and Pampha Bhusal expressed the belief that the new party would fulfill the mandate of social revolution. Meanwhile, General Secretary of the erstwhile CPN (US) Party Ghanashyam Bhusal and leader Ram Kumari Jhankri and some other leaders have not joined the new party, while expressing their protests against the unification.§

Title1: Government seeks neighbours’ support to set March 5 House elections in motion
Title2: Bihar Election 2025: A battle of caste, crime, and change
Paragraph1_of_URL1: As the poll date approaches, the government is preparing to request logistical support from two neighbouring countries—India and China—for a successful conduct of the polls four months away.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: The first phase of the Bihar Legislative Assembly election begins today, November 6, with the second phase scheduled for November 11 and results to be declared on November 14. The election is being watched with intense curiosity not only across India but also in neighboring Nepal, whose politics often mirrors the social complexity and generational aspirations visible in Bihar. With around 74.3 million registered voters deciding the fate of 243 constituencies, this election represents a decisive moment for a state that has long struggled to balance tradition, governance, and aspirations for change.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Following the willingness of the two countries to support, the Election Commission outlined the types of support it was willing to seek from the two countries and forwarded them to the Ministry of Finance.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: Bihar remains one of India’s most socially fragmented and economically deprived states. Around 88 percent of its population lives in rural areas, and the state continues to face deep structural inequality despite years of reform rhetoric. The social composition still shapes political outcomes: Extremely Backward Classes (EBCs) make up about 36 percent, Other Backward Classes (OBCs) 27 percent, and Scheduled Castes (SCs) nearly 20 percent of the population. The dominance of caste as a determinant of political loyalty remains, even as young voters show signs of gradual defiance of this traditional arithmetic.

Paragraph1_of_URL1: As the poll date approaches, the government is preparing to request logistical support from two neighbouring countries—India and China—for a successful conduct of the polls four months away.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: In the remote village of Bayal in Bajura, a woman was forced to give birth on the roadside just a year ago. Around one o'clock in the middle of the night, there was a commotion at the home of health worker Vinita Bisht Katuwal. Someone had arrived, urgently asking her to open the door. They explained that a pregnant woman on her way to the health post had gone into labor on the road. Hearing this news, Vinita immediately grabbed her delivery kit and ran into the darkness to reach the woman.

Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: Guru Nanak Jayanti is being observed by the Sikh community living in Nepal and different parts of the world today. Guru Nanak is the founder of Sikh religion. The spiritual leader had inspired the humanity for tolerance, compassion and love.

Title1: Government seeks neighbours’ support to set March 5 House elections in motion
Title2: Natural disasters, fire incidents on rise
Paragraph1_of_URL1: As the poll date approaches, the government is preparing to request logistical support from two neighbouring countries—India and China—for a successful conduct of the polls four months away.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: The fire incidents are on rise of late. The National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Authority (NDRRMA) informed that in 24 hours- from November 3 to 4, nine such incidents were recorded across the country. Jhapa, Morang, Mahottari, Sarlahi, Rautahat, Bara, Gorkha, Parbat and Kailali districts witnessed the fire incidents, the NDRRMA said, adding that total 18 incidents occurred in the country in two days alone, claiming the lives of three persons and injuring eight others.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Following the willingness of the two countries to support, the Election Commission outlined the types of support it was willing to seek from the two countries and forwarded them to the Ministry of Finance.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: The incidents caused the damages worth Rs 1.1 million. Storm occurred in Rasuwa caused massive damage. The avalanche damaged a local hotel at Langtang of Gosaikunda-4. Even the landslides occurred in Bhojpur, Khotang and Lalitpur districts.

Paragraph2_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: At a time when party split and unification bids are gaining pace among communist forces in the wake of Gen Z protest and election to the House of Representatives slated for coming March 5, Chairman of the CPN UML, KP Sharma Oli, and senior leader of the CPN (Unified Socialist), Jhalanath Khanal, held a meeting on Tuesday.

Title1: Government seeks neighbours’ support to set March 5 House elections in motion
Title2: NBA concerns government's decision of recalling ambassadors
Paragraph1_of_URL1: As the poll date approaches, the government is preparing to request logistical support from two neighbouring countries—India and China—for a successful conduct of the polls four months away.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: The Nepal Bar Association (NBA) has said that it is seriously concerned about the decision to recall the ambassadors, citing that the matter is under consideration in the Supreme Court.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Following the willingness of the two countries to support, the Election Commission outlined the types of support it was willing to seek from the two countries and forwarded them to the Ministry of Finance.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: In a press release issued today, NBA General Secretary Kedar Prasad Koirala has stated that there is serious concern regarding the government's recall of the ambassadors to work at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs while the matter related to the recent decision to call back the ambassador is under consideration in the Supreme Court and an interim order has been issued.

Title1: Government seeks neighbours’ support to set March 5 House elections in motion
Title2: Ten left forces, including CPN (Maoist Centre) and CPN (Unified Socialist), join hands
Paragraph1_of_URL1: As the poll date approaches, the government is preparing to request logistical support from two neighbouring countries—India and China—for a successful conduct of the polls four months away.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: Unification has been announced today among various leftist parties, including the CPN (Maoist Centre) and the CPN (Unified Socialist). At the special ceremony held today at local Bhrikuti Mandap, unity was announced among the leftist parties including the Maoist Centre, Unified Socialist, Nepal Socialist Party, Janasamajbadi Party Nepal, Nepal Communist Party, CPN (Maoist Socialist) and CPN (Communist).
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Following the willingness of the two countries to support, the Election Commission outlined the types of support it was willing to seek from the two countries and forwarded them to the Ministry of Finance.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: After the declaration of unification, the unified party has been christened as 'Nepali Communist Party'. Party top leaders and workers, including Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda', coordinator of the Maoist Centre, Madhav Kumar Nepal, chairman of the Unified Socialist, senior Maoist leader Narayan Kaji Shrestha, senior leader of the Unified Socialist Bamdev Gautam, Mahendra Ray Yadav, chairman of the Nepal Socialist Party, and Chiran Pun, general secretary of the Nepal Communist Party, among other leaders and party activists, attended the unity declaration gathering.

Title1: Government seeks neighbours’ support to set March 5 House elections in motion
Title2: Dahal elected coordinator of Nepali Communist Party, Nepal as joint-coordinator
Paragraph1_of_URL1: As the poll date approaches, the government is preparing to request logistical support from two neighbouring countries—India and China—for a successful conduct of the polls four months away.
Paragraph1_of_URL2: Kathmandu, Nov 5: Pushpa Kamal Dahal 'Prachanda' has been elected as coordinator of Nepali Communist Party, formed after the unification of 10 political parties including CPN (Maoist Centre) and CPN (Unified Socialist). The unification national conference organised here on Wednesday elected Madhav Kumar Nepal as its joint-coordinator. Member of THE presidium, Mahindra Raya Yadav, proposed Dahal to the post of coordinator and Nepal as joint-coordinator of the newly formed party.
Paragraph2_of_URL1: Following the willingness of the two countries to support, the Election Commission outlined the types of support it was willing to seek from the two countries and forwarded them to the Ministry of Finance.
Paragraph2_of_URL2: The conference had endorsed the proposal unanimously. On the occasion, senior leader of the Nepali Communist Party, Bamdev Gautam, leaders- Narayan Kaji Shrestha and Pampha Bhusal expressed the belief that the new party would fulfill the mandate of social revolution. Meanwhile, General Secretary of the erstwhile CPN (US) Party Ghanashyam Bhusal and leader Ram Kumari Jhankri and some other leaders have not joined the new party, while expressing their protests against the unification.§
